elements.content: A solvothermal reaction of ZnO, boric acid (B(OH)3), and aliphatic amines in a water−pyridine mixture gave four zinc borate phases of different dimensionalities: [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)], I (one-dimensional); [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O, II (two-dimensional); [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]·H2O, III (two-dimensional); and [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2], IV (three-dimensional). The structures are formed by the connectivity involving polyborate chains and layers with Zn2+ species. In all the compounds, the amine molecules act as the ligand binding either the same or different Zn centers. The formation of two different structures, II and IV, from the same amine by varying the reaction time is noteworthy. Transformation studies on II indicate that the formation of IV, from II, is facile and has been investigated for the first time. Two of the compounds, I and III, exhibit activity for second-order nonlinear optical behavior. The UV exposure of the sample indicates the absorption of all the UV radiation suggesting that the zinc borate compounds could be exploited for UV-blocking applications. The compounds have been characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, UV−vis, photoluminescence, and NMR studies.

elements.content: [B4O9H2] cyclic borate cluster units have been assembled to give zinc borates of different dimensionalities. The figure shows the condensation of one-dimensional borate chains to the two-dimensional layers.

elements.content: The advent of metal−organic framework compounds during the past decade or so has provided researchers with a new avenue to investigate solids that are different from the traditional silicate and phosphate frameworks. Persistent research over the years also established that the framework structures can accommodate a variety of anionic units such as sulfates, sulfites, selenates, and selenites. Recently, the borate anion is beginning to attract the attention of the synthetic chemists due to its flexible coordination preferences (trigonal, tetrahedral, etc.). Borate anions have been used extensively in solid state chemistry as a very good glass former, and its incorporation as part of the framework has been established in borosilicate and borophosphate structures. The boron incorporated frameworks exhibit unique physical and chemical properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The advent of metal-organic framework compounds during the past decade or so has provided researchers with a new avenue to investigate solids that are different from the traditional silicate and phosphate frameworks. Persistent research over the years also established that the framework structures can accommodate a variety of anionic units such as sulfates, sulfites, selenates, and selenites. Recently, the borate anion is beginning to attract the attention of the synthetic chemists due to its flexible coordination preferences (trigonal, tetrahedral, etc.). Borate anions have been used extensively in solid state chemistry as a very good glass former, and its incorporation as part of the framework has been established in borosilicate and borophosphate structures. The boron incorporated frameworks exhibit unique physical and chemical properties.

elements.content: In addition to the varying coordination nature of the borates, the ease of formation of rigid polyborate moieties adds to the intrigue in the study of borate-based compounds. Intense research over the years has resulted in the formation of borate-based framework compounds. In some of the borate compounds, good luminescence behavior has also been observed. It is also established that some of the borate phases do form in non-centrosymmetric space groups (nonpolar), which render them attractive for the study of nonlinear optical properties.

elements.content: The many attractive physical properties along with the knowledge of the synthetic methodology for the preparation of the crystalline borate phases prompted us to undertake a study on the formation of the zinc borate phases using solvothermal approaches. Our studies were successful and presently we have isolated four new zinc borate phases of different dimensionalities. Thus, the compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)], I, has a one-dimensional structure, [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O, II, and [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]·H2O, III, have two-dimensional structures, and [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2], IV, has three-dimensional structure. Here, we present the synthesis, structure, luminescence behavior, and transformation studies of the zinc borate phases.
elements.clean_text: The many attractive physical properties along with the knowledge of the synthetic methodology for the preparation of the crystalline borate phases prompted us to undertake a study on the formation of the zinc borate phases using solvothermal approaches. Our studies were successful and presently we have isolated four new zinc borate phases of different dimensionalities. Thus, the compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)], I, has a one-dimensional structure, [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]⋅H2O, II, and [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]⋅H2O, III, have two-dimensional structures, and [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2], IV, has three-dimensional structure. Here, we present the synthesis, structure, luminescence behavior, and transformation studies of the zinc borate phases.

elements.content: All the compounds were prepared employing the solvothermal method. In a typical synthesis, for [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I), ZnO (0.082 g, 1.0 mM) was dispersed in a mixture of a solution of 0.6 mL of H2O and 4.4 mL of pyridine. To this, boric acid (0.186 g, 3 mM) and 1,2-diaminopropane (1,2-DAP; 0.47 mL, 5 mM) were added under continuous stirring. The mixture was homogenized for 30 min at room temperature. The final mixture with a composition of 1:3:5:54:33 ZnO/H3BO3/1,2-DAP/pyridine/H2O was sealed in a 23 mL PTFE lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 7 days under autogenous pressure. The initial pH of the reaction mixture was 8, and there was no noticeable change in the pH after the reaction. The final product, containing large quantities of colorless rectangular crystals, was filtered, washed with deionized water under a vacuum, and dried at ambient conditions (yield ∼ 80% based on Zn). For the preparation of [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O (II) and [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV), 1,3-diaminopropane (1,3-DAP; 0.47 mL, 5 mM) and for [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]·H2O (III), trans-1,4-bis(3-aminopropyl)piperazine (APPIP; 1.03 mL, 5 mM) were used in place of 1,2-diaminopropane by keeping the composition and the reaction conditions identical to those in I. Compound IV was isolated from the same reaction mixture as that employed to prepare II, but by heating for a longer duration of 10 days at 180 °C. In all cases, we obtained good quality single crystals. Thus, colorless blocklike crystals of II, IV and rodlike crystals of III were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at ambient conditions (yield = ∼80% based on Zn).

Experimental Section

All the compounds were prepared employing the solvothermal method. In a typical synthesis, for [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I), ZnO (0.082 g, 1.0 mM) was dispersed in a mixture of a solution of 0.6 mL of H2O and 4.4 mL of pyridine. To this, boric acid (0.186 g, 3 mM) and 1,2-diaminopropane (1,2-DAP; 0.47 mL, 5 mM) were added under continuous stirring. The mixture was homogenized for 30 min at room temperature. The final mixture with a composition of 1:3:5:54:33 ZnO/H3BO3/1,2-DAP/pyridine/H2O was sealed in a 23 mL PTFE lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 7 days under autogenous pressure. The initial pH of the reaction mixture was 8, and there was no noticeable change in the pH after the reaction. The final product, containing large quantities of colorless rectangular crystals, was filtered, washed with deionized water under a vacuum, and dried at ambient conditions (yield ~ 80% based on Zn). For the preparation of [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]⋅H2O (II) and [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV), 1,3-diaminopropane (1,3-DAP; 0.47 mL, 5 mM) and for [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]⋅H2O (III), trans-1,4-bis(3-aminopropyl)piperazine (APPIP; 1.03 mL, 5 mM) were used in place of 1,2-diaminopropane by keeping the composition and the reaction conditions identical to those in I. Compound IV was isolated from the same reaction mixture as that employed to prepare II, but by heating for a longer duration of 10 days at 180 °C. In all cases, we obtained good quality single crystals. Thus, colorless blocklike crystals of II, IV and rodlike crystals of III were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at ambient conditions (yield = ~80% based on Zn).

elements.content: All the compounds were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared (IR), UV−vis, photoluminescence, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) studies. The PXRD patterns were recorded in the 2θ range 5−50° by using Cu Kα radiation (Philips, X’pert-Pro). The XRD patterns indicated that the products were new and the patterns were entirely consistent with the simulated XRD pattern generated based on the structures determined using the single crystal XRD (see ). IR spectroscopic studies have been carried out in the mid-IR region (4000 to 400 cm−1) on KBr pellets (Perkin−Elmer, SPECTRUM 1000). IR spectra of all the compounds were more or less similar and can be described in terms of six distinct regions (See ). (i) The compounds II−III have one sharp band at the 3475 cm−1 region, indicative of the presence of water molecules; (ii) a band at the 3265 cm−1 region can be assigned to the -OH group associated with the borate unit in all the structures; (iii) the bands at the 3110−2940 cm−1 region can be assigned to the stretching bands of the NH2 and CH2 groups; (iv) the bands in the region 1610−1340 cm−1 can be assigned to the N−H and C−H bending vibrations as well as to the asymmetric and symmetric modes of the amine molecules; (v) the strong bands at the 1350 and 1155 cm−1 region can be assigned to the trigonal boron; and (vi) the bands in the region of 1030−920 cm−1 are due to the tetrahedral boron species.

elements.content: The solid-state UV−visible absorbance spectroscopic studies were carried out for all the compounds at room temperature using BaSO4 as the background material (Perkin−Elmer model Lambda 35 UV−visible spectrometer). The powdered sample was placed inside a cuvette (75 mm × 80 mm × 20 mm) and the spectrum was recorded in the diffuse reflectance mode using an integrating sphere of radius 50 mm. The reflectance spectra were converted into an absorption-like spectra using the Kubelka−Munk function (see ). The solid-state photoluminescence spectroscopic studies were carried out at room temperature (Perkin−Elmer luminescence spectrometer model LS 55; see ).

elements.content: A suitable colorless single crystal of each compound was carefully selected under a polarizing microscope and glued to a thin glass fiber with a cyanoacrylate (superglue) adhesive. The single crystal data were collected on a Bruker AXS smart Apex CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K. The X-ray generator was operated at 50 kV and 35 mA using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data were collected with an ω scan width of 0.3°. A total of 606 frames were collected at three different settings of φ (0, 90, 180°) keeping the sample-to-detector distance fixed at 6.03 cm and the detector position (2θ) fixed at −25°. The data were reduced using SAINTPLUS, and an empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structure was solved and refined using SHELXL97 present in the WinGx suit of programs (Version 1.63.04a). The hydrogen positions were initially located in the difference Fourier maps, and for the final refinement the hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically ideal positions and refined using the riding mode. The hydrogen positions of one lattice water molecule in [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)].H2O (III) could not be located. The final refinement included atomic positions for all the atoms, anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms, and isotropic thermal parameters for all the hydrogen atoms. Full-matrix least-squares refinement against | F 2 | was carried out using the WinGx package of programs. Details of the structure solution and final refinements for all the structures are given in Table . The crystallographic data for compounds can be found in CCDC: 745774−745777 available free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Single-Crystal Structure Determination

A suitable colorless single crystal of each compound was carefully selected under a polarizing microscope and glued to a thin glass fiber with a cyanoacrylate (superglue) adhesive. The single crystal data were collected on a Bruker AXS smart Apex CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K. The X-ray generator was operated at 50 kV and 35 mA using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data were collected with an ω scan width of 0.3°. A total of 606 frames were collected at three different settings of φ (0, 90, 180°) keeping the sample-to-detector distance fixed at 6.03 cm and the detector position (2θ) fixed at -25°. The data were reduced using SAINTPLUS, and an empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structure was solved and refined using SHELXL97 present in the WinGx suit of programs (Version 1.63.04a). The hydrogen positions were initially located in the difference Fourier maps, and for the final refinement the hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically ideal positions and refined using the riding mode. The hydrogen positions of one lattice water molecule in [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)].H2O (III) could not be located. The final refinement included atomic positions for all the atoms, anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms, and isotropic thermal parameters for all the hydrogen atoms. Full-matrix least-squares refinement against | F  2  | was carried out using the WinGx package of programs. Details of the structure solution and final refinements for all the structures are given in Table . The crystallographic data for compounds can be found in CCDC: 745774-745777 available free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

The asymmetric unit of I contains 18 non-hydrogen atoms. There is only one crystallography independent Zn2+ ion, which is coordinated by two oxygen atoms of the borate unit and two nitrogen atoms of the 1,2-DAP molecule forming a distorted tetrahedral environment, (ZnO2N2, CN = 4). The Zn−O bond lengths are in the range 1.925(3)−2.005(3) Å [av. 1.965 Å] and the Zn−N bond lengths are in the range 2.041(4)−2.047(4) Å [av. 2.044 Å]. The O/N−Zn−O/N bond angles are in the range 87.1(1)−127.2(1)o. Of the two oxygen atoms that are connected to Zn, one is connected to a triangular boron center and the other to the tetrahedral boron center. The triangular boron atoms B(2) and B(4) have B−O distances in the range 1.339(6)−1.396(6) Å [av. = 1.366 Å], and the tetrahedral boron atoms B(1) and B(3) have longer B−O distances in the range 1.439(6)−1.539(5) Å [av. = 1.473 Å]. The O−B−O bond angles for the triangular boron atoms are in the range 116.2(4)−121.5(4)o [av. = 120.0°], and the O−B−O bond angles for the tetrahedral boron atoms are in the range 105.1(3)−115.5(3)o [av. = 109.4°]. The B atoms are bonded together, through B−O−B linkages, forming a cyclic polyborate cluster, [B4O9H2] with an average B−O−B bond angle of 112.6°. The various geometric parameters observed in I are comparable to other similar zincoborate structures reported in the literature. Selected bond distances are listed in Table .

Bond-valence sum [BVS] is defined as, S = exp((R o − R)/b), where S is the experimental bond valence, R = observed bond length, R o = nominal bond length and b = 0.37. For details see Brown, I. D. Chem. Rev. 2009, DOI: 10.1021/cr900053k.

The structure of I has a one-dimensional structure formed by the linkages involving the borate, the Zn2+ ion, and the organic amine molecule. Two triangular and two tetrahedral borate units are connected to form a [B4O9H2] cyclic borate unit. This cyclic borate may be considered as the basic building unit. The cyclic borate units are connected together to form an infinite one-dimensional helical polyborate chain (Figure a) with grooves arranged periodically on either side of the chain. The Zn (1,2-DAP) complex fits into the grooves and bond with the borate units forming the zinc borate structure (Figure b). The zinc borate chains are stabilized by the presence of O−H···O hydrogen bond interactions between the terminal B−OH units (Table ) (see ). Thus, O(8)H(8A)···O(4) [O···O, 2.88 Å] hydrogen bond interactions extend the structure supramolecularly into a two-dimensional layer along the “a” axis (Figure c) as well as to a three-dimensional borate structure (Figure d).

The asymmetric unit of II contains 19 non-hydrogen atoms. There is only one crystallographically independent Zn2+ ion, which is coordinated by two oxygen and two nitrogen neighbors and forms a distorted tetrahedral environment (ZnO2N2, CN = 4). The Zn−O bond lengths are in the range 1.938(1)−2.009(1) Å [av. 1.973 Å] and the Zn−N bond lengths in the range 2.005(1)−2.011(1) Å [av. 2.008 Å]. The O/N−Zn−O/N bond angles are in the range 92.45(6)−118.98(8)o. Similar to I, the B atoms have both the triangular and the tetrahedral coordination. The triangular boron atoms B(2) and B(4) have B−O distances in the range 1.359(3)−1.391(3) Å [av. = 1.371 Å] and the tetrahedral boron atoms B(1) and B(3) have longer B−O distances in the range 1.432(3)−1.522(3) Å [av. = 1.473 Å]. The O−B−O bond angles for the triangular boron atoms are in the range 115.96(19)−124.14(18)o [av. = 120.0°] and tetrahedral O−B−O bond angles are in the range 105.71(15)−115.60(17)o [av. = 109.42°]. The B atoms are also linked together through B−O−B linkages forming the cyclic cluster, [B4O9H2], with an average B−O−B bond angle of 112.8°.

elements.content: In compound II also we observed the identical basic building unit formed by the connectivity between the trigonal and tetrahedral borate units. The polyborate chain that results from the connectivity between the basic building units has the same helical arrangements with pockets, wherein the ZnO2N2 tetrahedral units are located (Figure a). Unlike I, here the Zn atoms are coordinated to nitrogen atoms of two different amine molecules. This extends the one-dimensional structure into a two-dimensional layered arrangement (Figure b). The terminal B−OH units play a supporting role for the stabilization of zinc borate layer due to the O−H···O intralayer hydrogen bond interactions between the terminal B−OH units and the framework borate oxygen atoms. The bound NH2 group of the 1,3-DAP molecules, due to the close proximity to the oxygens of the polyborate chains, also take part in intralayer hydrogen bond interactions. Thus, O(8)H(8A)···O(5) [O···O, 2.89 Å], N(2)H(7)···O(4) [N···O, 3.11 Å], and N(1)H(9)···O(7) [N···O, 3.23 Å] hydrogen bond interactions have been observed (see ). The zinc borate layers are supramolecularly stabilized by hydrogen bond interactions with the lattice water molecules (Figure c and Table ).

elements.content: In compound III also we observed a similar basic building unit formed by the connectivity between the trigonal and tetrahedral borate units. In addition, one terminal borate unit replaces the -OH group forming a cyclic borate of the formula [B5O11H3]. The cyclic borate units are bonded to form a similar helical chain arrangement with the -OB(OH)2 group hanging in place of one hydroxyl group. Similar to the structure of II, the ZnO2N2 tetrahedral units occupy the grooves in the one-dimensional polyborate chain to form a zinc borate one-dimensional chain (Figure a). The chains are linked through the amine molecules to form the two-dimensional layered arrangement (Figure b). The larger length of the bound amine molecules separates the two chains far apart. The layers are stabilized by the O−H···O hydrogen bond interactions between the terminal B−OH groups and the water molecules (Figure c). N−H···O and O−H···N interactions are also observed (Table ) (see ).

elements.content: In compound IV, we have the basic building unit formed by the connectivity between the trigonal and tetrahedral borate units. The connectivity between these units results in a polyborate layers rather than a simple one-dimensional chain structure observed in the earlier structures. The ZnO2N2 tetrahedral units are located within the apertures present in the layer borate structure (Figure a). The Zn atoms are coordinated to nitrogen atoms of two different amine molecules, which extend the two-dimensional structure into a three-dimensional one (Figure b). The three-dimensional structure also exhibits hydrogen bond interactions (Table ) (see ).

elements.content: TGA studies (Mettler-Toledo TG850) of all the compounds were carried out in an atmosphere of flowing oxygen (flow rate = 50 mL min−1) in the temperature range 30−850 °C (heating rate = 5 °C min−1). The results (see ) indicated that the compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I) was stable up to about 340 °C, after which a continuous weight loss was observed up to ∼850 °C. The total observed weight loss of 24% for I correlated with the loss of 1,2-DAP molecules (calcd 24%). The compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O (II) shows an initial weight loss of 6% in the range 30−180 °C, followed by a second weight loss of 26% at 310−850 °C. The total observed weight loss of 32% corresponds to the loss of water and the 1,3-DAP molecules (calcd 29%). The compound [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]·H2O (III) shows a continuous weight loss of 47%, which corresponds to the loss of water and the APPIP molecules (calcd 50%). Compound [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV) was found to the stable up to about 360 °C followed by a continuous weight loss up to ∼850 °C. The observed weight loss of 24% for IV corresponds with the loss of 1,3-DAP molecules (calcd 24%). The final calcined product in all the cases was found to be poorly crystalline, and the PXRD pattern indicated that it is a mixture of zinc borate and boron trioxide (ICDD No: 39-1126 and 13-0570). The TGA studies were also carried out in an atmosphere of flowing nitrogen (flow rate = 50 mL min−1) in the same temperature range (see ). The observed results did not show any difference compared to that observed in the presence of oxygen. The total weight loss under N2 atmosphere was found to be less compared to the studies under O2 atmosphere (see ), which could be due to the incomplete oxidation of the amine molecules under the N2 atmosphere.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

TGA studies (Mettler-Toledo TG850) of all the compounds were carried out in an atmosphere of flowing oxygen (flow rate = 50 mL min-1) in the temperature range 30-850 °C (heating rate = 5 °C min-1). The results (see ) indicated that the compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I) was stable up to about 340 °C, after which a continuous weight loss was observed up to ~850 °C. The total observed weight loss of 24% for I correlated with the loss of 1,2-DAP molecules (calcd 24%). The compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]⋅H2O (II) shows an initial weight loss of 6% in the range 30-180 °C, followed by a second weight loss of 26% at 310-850 °C. The total observed weight loss of 32% corresponds to the loss of water and the 1,3-DAP molecules (calcd 29%). The compound [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]⋅H2O (III) shows a continuous weight loss of 47%, which corresponds to the loss of water and the APPIP molecules (calcd 50%). Compound [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV) was found to the stable up to about 360 °C followed by a continuous weight loss up to ~850 °C. The observed weight loss of 24% for IV corresponds with the loss of 1,3-DAP molecules (calcd 24%). The final calcined product in all the cases was found to be poorly crystalline, and the PXRD pattern indicated that it is a mixture of zinc borate and boron trioxide (ICDD No: 39-1126 and 13-0570). The TGA studies were also carried out in an atmosphere of flowing nitrogen (flow rate = 50 mL min-1) in the same temperature range (see ). The observed results did not show any difference compared to that observed in the presence of oxygen. The total weight loss under N2 atmosphere was found to be less compared to the studies under O2 atmosphere (see ), which could be due to the incomplete oxidation of the amine molecules under the N2 atmosphere.

elements.content: The zinc borate compounds I, II, III, and IV have similar connectivity that involves bonding between the Zn2+ ions, the trigonal and the tetrahedral borate units, and the organic amine molecules. The noticeable structural aspect is the formation of the same building unit in all the compounds along with the polyborate chain structure. In [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV), the polyborate chain units are further condensed to form a two-dimensional borate layer. In all the compounds, the polyborate units form a helical chain with major grooves formed at the pitch of the helix, where the Zn species are nestled. The presence of 1,2-DAP in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I) gives rise to a simple chain structure, which could be due to the shorter length of the amine. In order to investigate this assumption, we attempted to prepare zinc borate phases in the presence of ethylene diamine. Our efforts have not been successful as we formed only a powdered sample and we could not isolate any single crystalline material that would be suitable for structure determination using the single crystal methods (see ). The other compounds, however, have the amine molecule extending the dimensionality by bridging with the Zn centers from two different chains/layers.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Comparison

The zinc borate compounds I, II, III, and IV have similar connectivity that involves bonding between the Zn2+ ions, the trigonal and the tetrahedral borate units, and the organic amine molecules. The noticeable structural aspect is the formation of the same building unit in all the compounds along with the polyborate chain structure. In [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV), the polyborate chain units are further condensed to form a two-dimensional borate layer. In all the compounds, the polyborate units form a helical chain with major grooves formed at the pitch of the helix, where the Zn species are nestled. The presence of 1,2-DAP in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I) gives rise to a simple chain structure, which could be due to the shorter length of the amine. In order to investigate this assumption, we attempted to prepare zinc borate phases in the presence of ethylene diamine. Our efforts have not been successful as we formed only a powdered sample and we could not isolate any single crystalline material that would be suitable for structure determination using the single crystal methods (see ). The other compounds, however, have the amine molecule extending the dimensionality by bridging with the Zn centers from two different chains/layers.

elements.content: It is worthwhile pondering the formation of the three-dimensional structure of [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] as it contains borate layers as part of the structure. As mentioned earlier, IV was prepared using the same condition as that was employed for the synthesis of [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O (II), but with longer duration. The longer heating appears to help in the polymerization of the terminal B−OH units, which formed B−O−H···O−B hydrogen bonds in the structure of [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O (Figure c). Since the polyborate chains are favorably disposed toward each other in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O, the formation of borate layers in [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] could be expected. We have proposed a possible mechanism of formation of the borate layers from the basic building unit (Figure ). It is clear that the formation of borate layers is indeed facile. The longer heating of the reaction mixtures of [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I) and [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]·H2O (III), however, did not yield any higher dimensional products. It is likely the terminal CH3 group of the amine molecules could have played a role in preventing the formation of a layered borate in I. In addition, both the nitrogen atoms of the amine molecules are bound to the same Zn center, which would not be conducive for the collapse of the 1D polyborate chains. In III, the amine molecules are long and the interactions between the terminal B−OH units are through the lattice water molecules, which effectively blocks the polymerization of the borate chains to form a layered borate structure.

elements.content: The close structural relationship that exists between the 1D and the 2D polyborate units in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O (II) and [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV) prompted us to investigate the possible interconversion between the compounds. For this, we have taken compound II (100 mg) in an autoclave with the same reaction mixture of water and pyridine (0.6 and 4.4 mL, respectively) and heated at 180 °C for varying periods of time (see ). Our initial direct preparation from the constituent reactants indicated that II forms after 7 days at 180 °C, whereas IV is formed after 10 days of heating (see ). This suggests that there is a possibility for the formation of IV from II. As expected, we find the formation of the compound IV within 12 h of heating of II. The formation of IV gradually increases over a period of time and the pure phase of IV was obtained after 3 days. A plot of the relative formation of IV as a function of time also clearly shows that compound IV is formed in 3 days of heating II (Figure ). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study of the transformation of one phase into another phase in the family of amine templated borate structures.
elements.clean_text:
Transformation Reactions

The close structural relationship that exists between the 1D and the 2D polyborate units in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]⋅H2O (II) and [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV) prompted us to investigate the possible interconversion between the compounds. For this, we have taken compound II (100 mg) in an autoclave with the same reaction mixture of water and pyridine (0.6 and 4.4 mL, respectively) and heated at 180 °C for varying periods of time (see ). Our initial direct preparation from the constituent reactants indicated that II forms after 7 days at 180 °C, whereas IV is formed after 10 days of heating (see ). This suggests that there is a possibility for the formation of IV from II. As expected, we find the formation of the compound IV within 12 h of heating of II. The formation of IV gradually increases over a period of time and the pure phase of IV was obtained after 3 days. A plot of the relative formation of IV as a function of time also clearly shows that compound IV is formed in 3 days of heating II (Figure ). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study of the transformation of one phase into another phase in the family of amine templated borate structures.

elements.content: Room temperature UV−vis spectra were obtained in the diffuse reflectance mode for all the compounds in powder form. The observed spectra were converted to an absorption like spectra using the Kubelka−Munk function (see ). All the compounds exhibit one main peak centered around 365 nm. It has been shown that the polycrystalline powder of ZnO also shows an absorption band around 365 nm. The corresponding calculated band gap is ∼3.15 eV, which is comparable with wide-band gap semiconductors. Since it has been established that the ZnO absorbs most of the harmful UV radiations, we wanted to examine the present compounds for such behavior. When the zinc borate phases, I−IV, was exposed to UV radiation (λ = 365 nm), the samples turned completely brownish black (Figure ) indicating that the present compounds also absorb the UV radiation. This observation suggests the present materials can be considered for UV-blocking applications.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties

Room temperature UV-vis spectra were obtained in the diffuse reflectance mode for all the compounds in powder form. The observed spectra were converted to an absorption like spectra using the Kubelka-Munk function (see ). All the compounds exhibit one main peak centered around 365 nm. It has been shown that the polycrystalline powder of ZnO also shows an absorption band around 365 nm. The corresponding calculated band gap is ~3.15 eV, which is comparable with wide-band gap semiconductors. Since it has been established that the ZnO absorbs most of the harmful UV radiations, we wanted to examine the present compounds for such behavior. When the zinc borate phases, I-IV, was exposed to UV radiation (λ = 365 nm), the samples turned completely brownish black (Figure ) indicating that the present compounds also absorb the UV radiation. This observation suggests the present materials can be considered for UV-blocking applications.

elements.content: The change of color of the samples under (a) visible light and (b) UV illumination.
elements.clean_text: 7  The change of color of the samples under (a) visible light and (b) UV illumination.

elements.content: We have also carried out the photoluminescence studies on the present compounds in the solid state using an excitation wavelength of 365 nm. We have observed four emission bands centered around 444, 465, 486, and 530 nm. All these emissions are in the visible region. Earlier studies on the photoluminescence behavior of the zinc borate compounds also suggest that the photoluminescence of zinc borates are complex. The emissions at 444 nm could be due to the strongly localized self-trapped excitonic state, which is an intrinsic behavior of the zinc borate compounds. The emission bands at 465 nm may be due to the defect sites in the zinc borate compounds. The peak at 530 nm may be due to the ionized vacancies in the zinc borates. Similar emissions have also been observed for doped ZnO compounds.

The emission bands at 465 nm may be due to the defect sites in the zinc borate compounds. The peak at 530 nm may be due to the ionized vacancies in the zinc borates. Similar emissions have also been observed for doped ZnO compounds.

elements.content: Of the four zinc borate compounds, compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I) and [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]·H2O (III) are formed with the space group P212121 (No. 19) and P21 (No. 4), respectively. The formation of compounds with these space groups suggests that they could exhibit second-order nonlinear optical effects. We have carried out a study of the second harmonic generation (SHG) property on the powdered samples of I and III using a laser of beam energy 2.83 mJ/pulse. Compounds I and III exhibited responses to the SHG behavior with a response of 24 and 29 mV, respectively, which is lower than the standard KDP material (KH2PO4, 175 mV). It is likely that the current materials exhibit lower value due to the random orientation of the crystallites in the power form as we have not been able to prepare sizable single crystals with which to perform the oriented SHG studies.
elements.clean_text:
Nonlinear Optical Studies

Of the four zinc borate compounds, compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I) and [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]⋅H2O (III) are formed with the space group P212121 (No. 19) and P21 (No. 4), respectively. The formation of compounds with these space groups suggests that they could exhibit second-order nonlinear optical effects. We have carried out a study of the second harmonic generation (SHG) property on the powdered samples of I and III using a laser of beam energy 2.83 mJ/pulse. Compounds I and III exhibited responses to the SHG behavior with a response of 24 and 29 mV, respectively, which is lower than the standard KDP material (KH2PO4, 175 mV). It is likely that the current materials exhibit lower value due to the random orientation of the crystallites in the power form as we have not been able to prepare sizable single crystals with which to perform the oriented SHG studies.

elements.content: The 11B MAS NMR spectroscopic studies have been carried out on a Bruker-AVIII 500 spectrometer. H3BO3 was used as the external standard, and the chemical shifts are relative to the boric acid. The observed 11B spectra and the chemical shifts observed appear to support the findings of the single crystal study. All the four compounds exhibit similar 11B MAS NMR signals. Thus, one doublet in the range −3 to −12 ppm and a singlet in the range −18 to −20 ppm have been observed (Figure ). It has been shown that the second-order nuclear electric quadrupolar interactions in trigonal boron species would affect the NMR signal and leads to a shift in the upfield region. Thus, the signal observed around −3 to −12 ppm would correspond to the three-coordinated boron species. The singlet observed around −18 to −20 ppm would, then, correspond to the four-coordinated boron species. In addition, we have also attempted to correlate the 11B NMR signals with the bond strength values calculated employing the method of Brown (see ). In all the cases, we observed that the bond strength values for the trigonal boron were in the range 6.0−6.5, whereas the bond strength values for the tetrahedral boron were >8.5. It has been shown that the isotropic chemical shifts of the NMR spectra shift up/downfield depending on the bond-strength of the probe nucleus. Thus, in the present compounds the lower bond strength values indicate that the trigonal boron would exhibit higher chemical shift compared to the tetrahedral boron, which is the observed behavior.
elements.clean_text:
MAS NMR Spectra of 11B

The 11B MAS NMR spectroscopic studies have been carried out on a Bruker-AVIII 500 spectrometer. H3BO3 was used as the external standard, and the chemical shifts are relative to the boric acid. The observed 11B spectra and the chemical shifts observed appear to support the findings of the single crystal study. All the four compounds exhibit similar 11B MAS NMR signals. Thus, one doublet in the range -3 to -12 ppm and a singlet in the range -18 to -20 ppm have been observed (Figure ). It has been shown that the second-order nuclear electric quadrupolar interactions in trigonal boron species would affect the NMR signal and leads to a shift in the upfield region. Thus, the signal observed around -3 to -12 ppm would correspond to the three-coordinated boron species. The singlet observed around -18 to -20 ppm would, then, correspond to the four-coordinated boron species. In addition, we have also attempted to correlate the 11B NMR signals with the bond strength values calculated employing the method of Brown (see ). In all the cases, we observed that the bond strength values for the trigonal boron were in the range 6.0-6.5, whereas the bond strength values for the tetrahedral boron were >8.5. It has been shown that the isotropic chemical shifts of the NMR spectra shift up/downfield depending on the bond-strength of the probe nucleus. Thus, in the present compounds the lower bond strength values indicate that the trigonal boron would exhibit higher chemical shift compared to the tetrahedral boron, which is the observed behavior.

elements.content: The synthesis and structure of a family of zinc borate compounds with one-, two-, and three-dimensionally extended structures have been accomplished. The formation of [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV), a three-dimensional structure, from the same reaction mixture employed for the preparation of [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O (II), by heating for longer duration is noteworthy. Direct transformation of a layered borate, II, to a three-dimensional borate, IV, has been observed for the first time. The absorption of all the UV radiation by the zinc borate phases indicates an effective and new UV-blocking material, which could find applications. The borate-based framework phases are beginning to emerge as a new class of compounds and the structural diversity that has been observed so far indicates that the borates are also capable of exhibiting a variety of structures similar to the more well established families such as the phosphates.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The synthesis and structure of a family of zinc borate compounds with one-, two-, and three-dimensionally extended structures have been accomplished. The formation of [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV), a three-dimensional structure, from the same reaction mixture employed for the preparation of [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]⋅H2O (II), by heating for longer duration is noteworthy. Direct transformation of a layered borate, II, to a three-dimensional borate, IV, has been observed for the first time. The absorption of all the UV radiation by the zinc borate phases indicates an effective and new UV-blocking material, which could find applications. The borate-based framework phases are beginning to emerge as a new class of compounds and the structural diversity that has been observed so far indicates that the borates are also capable of exhibiting a variety of structures similar to the more well established families such as the phosphates.

elements.content: Bond angles observed in I−IV; boron−oxygen bond lengths and the calculated bond strengths (S) at boron and at oxygen in I−IV; powder XRD (CuKα) patterns, IR spectra, diffuse reflectance spectra, and photoluminescence of compounds I−IV; the important hydrogen bond interactions (inter-chain) of I−IV and in the two-dimensional and three-dimensional supramolecular arrangement; TGA studies; PXRD patterns. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: All the compounds were prepared employing the solvothermal method. In a typical synthesis, for [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I), ZnO (0.082 g, 1.0 mM) was dispersed in a mixture of a solution of 0.6 mL of H2O and 4.4 mL of pyridine. To this, boric acid (0.186 g, 3 mM) and 1,2-diaminopropane (1,2-DAP; 0.47 mL, 5 mM) were added under continuous stirring. The mixture was homogenized for 30 min at room temperature. The final mixture with a composition of 1:3:5:54:33 ZnO/H3BO3/1,2-DAP/pyridine/H2O was sealed in a 23 mL PTFE lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 7 days under autogenous pressure. The initial pH of the reaction mixture was 8, and there was no noticeable change in the pH after the reaction. The final product, containing large quantities of colorless rectangular crystals, was filtered, washed with deionized water under a vacuum, and dried at ambient conditions (yield ∼ 80% based on Zn). For the preparation of [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O (II) and [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV), 1,3-diaminopropane (1,3-DAP; 0.47 mL, 5 mM) and for [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]·H2O (III), trans-1,4-bis(3-aminopropyl)piperazine (APPIP; 1.03 mL, 5 mM) were used in place of 1,2-diaminopropane by keeping the composition and the reaction conditions identical to those in I. Compound IV was isolated from the same reaction mixture as that employed to prepare II, but by heating for a longer duration of 10 days at 180 °C. In all cases, we obtained good quality single crystals. Thus, colorless blocklike crystals of II, IV and rodlike crystals of III were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at ambient conditions (yield = ∼80% based on Zn).

Experimental Section

All the compounds were prepared employing the solvothermal method. In a typical synthesis, for [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I), ZnO (0.082 g, 1.0 mM) was dispersed in a mixture of a solution of 0.6 mL of H2O and 4.4 mL of pyridine. To this, boric acid (0.186 g, 3 mM) and 1,2-diaminopropane (1,2-DAP; 0.47 mL, 5 mM) were added under continuous stirring. The mixture was homogenized for 30 min at room temperature. The final mixture with a composition of 1:3:5:54:33 ZnO/H3BO3/1,2-DAP/pyridine/H2O was sealed in a 23 mL PTFE lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 7 days under autogenous pressure. The initial pH of the reaction mixture was 8, and there was no noticeable change in the pH after the reaction. The final product, containing large quantities of colorless rectangular crystals, was filtered, washed with deionized water under a vacuum, and dried at ambient conditions (yield ~ 80% based on Zn). For the preparation of [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]⋅H2O (II) and [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV), 1,3-diaminopropane (1,3-DAP; 0.47 mL, 5 mM) and for [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]⋅H2O (III), trans-1,4-bis(3-aminopropyl)piperazine (APPIP; 1.03 mL, 5 mM) were used in place of 1,2-diaminopropane by keeping the composition and the reaction conditions identical to those in I. Compound IV was isolated from the same reaction mixture as that employed to prepare II, but by heating for a longer duration of 10 days at 180 °C. In all cases, we obtained good quality single crystals. Thus, colorless blocklike crystals of II, IV and rodlike crystals of III were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at ambient conditions (yield = ~80% based on Zn).

The total observed weight loss of 24% for I correlated with the loss of 1,2-DAP molecules (calcd 24%). The compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O (II) shows an initial weight loss of 6% in the range 30−180 °C, followed by a second weight loss of 26% at 310−850 °C. The total observed weight loss of 32% corresponds to the loss of water and the 1,3-DAP molecules (calcd 29%). The compound [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]·H2O (III) shows a continuous weight loss of 47%, which corresponds to the loss of water and the APPIP molecules (calcd 50%). Compound [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV) was found to the stable up to about 360 °C followed by a continuous weight loss up to ∼850 °C. The observed weight loss of 24% for IV corresponds with the loss of 1,3-DAP molecules (calcd 24%). The final calcined product in all the cases was found to be poorly crystalline, and the PXRD pattern indicated that it is a mixture of zinc borate and boron trioxide (ICDD No: 39-1126 and 13-0570). The TGA studies were also carried out in an atmosphere of flowing nitrogen (flow rate = 50 mL min−1) in the same temperature range (see ). The observed results did not show any difference compared to that observed in the presence of oxygen. The total weight loss under N2 atmosphere was found to be less compared to the studies under O2 atmosphere (see ), which could be due to the incomplete oxidation of the amine molecules under the N2 atmosphere.

Thermal Stability

TGA studies (Mettler-Toledo TG850) of all the compounds were carried out in an atmosphere of flowing oxygen (flow rate = 50 mL min-1) in the temperature range 30-850 °C (heating rate = 5 °C min-1). The results (see ) indicated that the compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)] (I) was stable up to about 340 °C, after which a continuous weight loss was observed up to ~850 °C. The total observed weight loss of 24% for I correlated with the loss of 1,2-DAP molecules (calcd 24%). The compound [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]⋅H2O (II) shows an initial weight loss of 6% in the range 30-180 °C, followed by a second weight loss of 26% at 310-850 °C. The total observed weight loss of 32% corresponds to the loss of water and the 1,3-DAP molecules (calcd 29%). The compound [Zn(B5O10H3)(C10H24N4)]⋅H2O (III) shows a continuous weight loss of 47%, which corresponds to the loss of water and the APPIP molecules (calcd 50%). Compound [Zn2(B8O15H2)(C3H10N2)2] (IV) was found to the stable up to about 360 °C followed by a continuous weight loss up to ~850 °C. The observed weight loss of 24% for IV corresponds with the loss of 1,3-DAP molecules (calcd 24%). The final calcined product in all the cases was found to be poorly crystalline, and the PXRD pattern indicated that it is a mixture of zinc borate and boron trioxide (ICDD No: 39-1126 and 13-0570). The TGA studies were also carried out in an atmosphere of flowing nitrogen (flow rate = 50 mL min-1) in the same temperature range (see ). The observed results did not show any difference compared to that observed in the presence of oxygen. The total weight loss under N2 atmosphere was found to be less compared to the studies under O2 atmosphere (see ), which could be due to the incomplete oxidation of the amine molecules under the N2 atmosphere.

cln_elements.content: (a) The one-dimensional borate chain observed in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)], I. (b) The zinc borate chain in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)], I. Note that the ZnO2N2 units are located in the grooves of the helical chain (see text). (c) View of the two-dimensional layer formed through B−O−H···O−B hydrogen bonds. Dotted lines are the hydrogen bonds. (d) Packing diagram of I showing the three-dimensional arrangement formed by the hydrogen bonds (dotted lines).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The one-dimensional borate chain observed in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)], I. (b) The zinc borate chain in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)], I. Dotted lines are the hydrogen bonds. (d) Packing diagram of I showing the three-dimensional arrangement formed by the hydrogen bonds (dotted lines).

cln_elements.content: (a) The one-dimensional zinc borate chain in [Zn(B4O8H2)(C3H10N2)]·H2O, II. (b) The polyhedral view of the two-dimensional layer in II. Note that the layers are formed by the amine molecules bonding with the Zn centers of two different chains. (c) The arrangement of layers in the “ac” plane. Note the formation of the three-dimensional connectivity via the water molecules (see text).
